title: Merge pull request #1 from airbnb/master
body: Update

title: Use 80 chars for consistency with comment above
body: Comment just above this mentions "Strings longer than 80 characters should be written across multiple lines using string concatenation".  It might make sense to use 80 characters in the example.

title: Make use of GitHub's default anchors.
body: I've removed the custom `..` tags and the TOC is now relying on the generated anchors, so that not the full heading but only the anchor in front of it is clickable. Which makes the page calmer. Also updated the back to top link from **[[⬆]](#TOC)** to **[⬆ back to top](#table-of-contents)** and repositioned them to not be part of the list item.

title: Add Digitpaint to list of organisations using this style guide
body: Awesome styleguide; we use it intensively (and added a bit of our own sauce :) )

title: [DO NOT MERGE!] Different way of declaring variables.
body:
What if we move away from declaring all variables with one `var` to using one `var` per variable?
It reads better (no need to argue on how to indent 2nd and further lines) and it's not our job to optimise code manually.

Any thoughts?

title: Add Money Advice Service to list of organisations using this style guide
Naming Conventions and private variables
body: I disagree with the idea that naming a private variable should begin with _.  If you really need a private variable why not create an object and wrap your variable with setters and getters.  If you use _ and someone thinks they need that variable or method they will use it.  I have seen it before lots of times.  Conventions work when you are doing ruby and rails type implementation and the conventions are required for things to work right, but when conventions are guidlines there is no stopping people from behaving badly.  Also this conflicts with the _this, which someone could easily do this._this.

title: Added array item stacking
body: @bdoms @amdtech @doomspork @GabKlein

title: Variable declaration
Detail: 0 is coerced into false too
Can't forget about the ! before a module right? ;)
body: Might make people curious about this guide or might remind people about the bang.

title: added Peerby to list of organizations that use this guide
body: We found that your comprehensive list so matching to our coding standards that we figured we might as well adopt it completely.

title: Big update with better conventions
body: Better conventions for boolean var names, function/method definitions with a space between the name opposed to invoking a function/method to distinguish the two. Use multiline var expressions instead of comma separated for vars with values. Included a section about a solid toType function.

title: About Name your functions
Unclear code example in variables section
good shoud replace better~~~
body: sorry ,I want to test~~

title: Add .jshintrc
body:
This adds a `.jshintrc` to the `linters/` directory. I just copied over
the settings from the `SublimeLinter` file, de-nesting the JSON object
by one level.

It means we'll have to maintain both files, but it's good to have a
basic `.jshintrc` for those of us that aren't using JSHint through
Sublime Text.

As requested in https://github.com/airbnb/rendr/pull/239.

@hshoff what do you think?

title: Avoid leading pluses
body: Please add note about that. :)

title: Enforce 'use strict'
body:
As stated in the [Modules section](https://github.com/airbnb/javascript#modules), `'use strict'` needs to be declared at the top of a module

[JSHint has an option](http://www.jshint.com/docs/options/#strict) for something like this by enforcing the declaration of `'use strict'` at the top function scope.

title: Add a missing `.hide()` for consistency's sake.
body: The section about jQuery suggests different ways of finding an element, and in all of the examples the selected element is `.hide()`-ed. Except the last example, for some reason. Assuming it was a mistake to not call `.hide()` on that last one, I've fixed the discrepancy.

title: changes to how strings are concatenated
body: Changed the way strings are concatenated, by making the concatenation at the beginning of a line, which seems like a bit cleaner solution.

title: updated the benchmarks of the join and string concatenation
body: see https://gist.github.com/yorkie/7837575, please.

title: Add 3rd Party Library Section
body:
If my `<script scr="3rd_party.js">` is being loaded into someone's site, what's the etiquette?

Do I only get a single global variable like '__myLibrary = {this.code=...}' (double underscore prefix)? Should this still be wrapped in an anonymous function?

If I'm injecting html/style/script tags, do they always get appended to the end of the head or body? Is prefixing every id/class with "myLibrary_varName" enough to avoid collisions?

When is it ok to use iframes, document.write, etc.?

When injecting an overlay do I just set the z-index to "2147483647"? Once my content needs to go away, can I set it to "display:none;" or do I need to remove it from the DOM?

title: Spaces Around Operators
body: This is the convention throughout the guide itself, but isn't specifically called out anywhere.

title: 32-bit integers and bitwise operators explained with example of issues
body:
I've added this example to russian translation when I've got question from one of our juniors "what's the limits of wise use of bitwise operators". Some modern high-level developers never heard about 2-byte shortInt, 4-byte Int an 8-byte longInt :worried:
So it could be useful

title: Update SublimeLinter.sublime-settings to include maxlen enforcement
body:
The Airbnb guide states: "Strings longer than 80 characters should be written across multiple lines using string concatenation."

I propose to add the maxlen option to enforce this rule: http://www.jshint.com/docs/options/#maxlen

However maxlen enforces the entire source code, not just a line of String. I would like to hear your thoughts on whether that is a beneficial enforcement to keep JS code at a set width.
